title: Reduce package size with `options.extras_require` feature of setuptools
body:
At the moment, the package is quite heavy due to certain dependencies like `transformers`. This makes it difficult to deploy on serverless solutions like AWS Lambda.

Is it possible to create optional dependencies to make the package lightweight? https://setuptools.pypa.io/en/latest/userguide/dependency_management.html#optional-dependencies

I have not dug too deep into the source code to understand if there are any optional dependencies but I think it would be quite beneficial from a DevOps perspective to tackle this problem.

title: How to use custom prompts and different default prompts?
body:
I can see only this example in the documentation: https://gpt-index.readthedocs.io/en/latest/how_to/custom_prompts.html

Does this mean it only works with GPTTreeIndex and not with GPTSimpleVectorIndex?

If I use it the same way on GPTSimpleVectorIndex I get an error:
`TypeError: BaseGPTIndex.__init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'summary_template'`

My code:
```
query_str = user_text
prompt = (
"---------------------\n"
"{context_str}"
"\n---------------------\n"
"PROMPT TEXT"

f"Customer: {query_str}\n"
"AI:"
)

SUMMARY_PROMPT = SummaryPrompt(prompt)
index = GPTSimpleVectorIndex(documents, summary_template=SUMMARY_PROMPT)
```

And I can see there are lots of different default prompts found in [here](https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/blob/main/gpt_index/prompts/default_prompts.py) but no example or explanation how to use them in the documentation.

I'd really like to use them just have no idea how.

title: Upsert behavior corrected (don't generate random id's when there's collisions)
body:
You don't need to generate a random id here. That is not the expected behavior of an upsert operation. 

https://docs.pinecone.io/reference/upsert

title: [Breakage] extra_index in SimpleIndexDict returning None with newly serialized GPTSimpleVectorIndex
body:
When upgrading from gpt-index==0.3.3 to llama-index==0.4.8, indexes saved with `GPTSimpleVectorIndex.save_to_disk` no longer persist `extra_info` correctly to documents.

Before: `extra_info` would be assigned correctly at the top level when `GPTSimpleVectorIndex.load_from_disk` is called

After: `extra_info` is not assigned to the SimpleIndexDict top level object, instead it needs to be accessed through `nodes_dict` which doesn't make sense, since each SimpleDictIndex in `GPTSimpleVectorIndex.docstore` should correspond to an individual document.

title: AssertionError: The batch size should not be larger than 2048.
body:
Using the following code, trying to load emails in csv format exported to a single file from Outlook I get the following error.

`import os
from llama_index import GPTSimpleVectorIndex, SimpleDirectoryReader


def read_file(filepath):
    with open(filepath, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as infile:
        return infile.read()


os.environ["OPENAI_API_KEY"] = read_file('openaiapikey.txt')

if os.path.exists("data/emailindex.json"):
    # load from disk
    index = GPTSimpleVectorIndex.load_from_disk('data/emailindex.json')
else:
    documents = SimpleDirectoryReader('data/input').load_data()
    index = GPTSimpleVectorIndex(documents)
    # save to disk
    index.save_to_disk('data/emailindex.json')

while True:
    prompt = input("Prompt: ")
    response = index.query(prompt)
    print(response)
`

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Users\paul.eden\AppData\Local\Packages\PythonSoftwareFoundation.Python.3.10_qbz5n2kfra8p0\LocalCache\local-packages\Python310\site-packages\tenacity\__init__.py", line 409, in __call__
    result = fn(*args, **kwargs)
  File "C:\Users\paul.eden\AppData\Local\Packages\PythonSoftwareFoundation.Python.3.10_qbz5n2kfra8p0\LocalCache\local-packages\Python310\site-packages\llama_index\embeddings\openai.py", line 123, in get_embeddings
    assert len(list_of_text) <= 2048, "The batch size should not be larger than 2048."
AssertionError: The batch size should not be larger than 2048.

title: refactor _add_document_to_index in weaviate.py to use multithreaded batch import
body:
The weaviate python client supports [multithreaded batch import](https://weaviate.io/developers/weaviate/client-libraries/python#new-multi-threading-batch-import-weaviate-client390) to import multiple documents in parallel.

We should refactor [_add_document_to_index](https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/blob/7125b16393728bc3da05c4d89d5977cc1ab4a59f/gpt_index/indices/vector_store/weaviate.py#L99-L113) to take advantage of this feature.

The current implementation creates [a batch size of 1](https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/blob/main/gpt_index/readers/weaviate/data_structs.py#L227) and then [flushes it](https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/blob/7125b16393728bc3da05c4d89d5977cc1ab4a59f/gpt_index/readers/weaviate/data_structs.py#L143).

How would `GPTSimpleVectorIndex` react if I were to insert a document with `doc_id` of an already present document?

```python
document = Document(..., doc_id="id")
index.insert(document)

updated_document = Document(..., doc_id="id")

#     👇 What will happen here?

```


Will it just update the document/nodes/vectors? Is it even safe to do so?

index.query("Who is donald trump?")`

title: Refactor vector store index
body:
### Summary
* Composition over inheritance: A `GPTVectorStoreIndex` has a `VectorStore`. 
* Some benefits are:
  * Generally decouple index logic & data structures from vector store.
  * More explicit `VectorStore` interface, easier to implement new vector store backends against it.
  * No longer necessary to define backend specific index logic and queries, e.g. `GPTQdrantIndexQuery`.

### API impact and backwards compatibility
* We can now construct `GPTVectorStoreIndex` by explicitly passing in a `VectorStore`
> vector_store = PineconeVectorStore(pinecone_index=pinecone_index)
> index = GPTVectorStoreIndex(documents, vector_store)
* We still allow the syntactic sugar as before
> index = GPTPineconeIndex(documents, pinecone_index)
* This PR will break loading old saved indices (since we change how some configurations are stored under the hood).

### Todos

- [ ] Add docs
- [ ] Pull in changes from https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/pull/505

title: FlexGen with GPT Index
body:
FlexGen has just been released - https://github.com/Ying1123/FlexGen

FlexGen is a high-throughput generation engine for running large language models with limited GPU memory (e.g., a 16GB T4 or a 24GB RTX3090 gaming card!).

Would it be possible to run GPT Index with it?

title: testing/science underlying continuation prompts
body:
The default continuation prompt is:

`Given the new context, refine the original answer to better answer the question. If the context isn't useful, return the original answer.`

Out of curiosity (and always wanting to understand the fundamentals of things), what is the basis for this phrasing?  Was it arrived at entirely by trial and error?  Is there any variation if you substitute words like "interesting" for "useful", or add "very" useful (which would emphasize stuff first read)?  In a perfect world, there would be a deterministic, or at least a known, link between the internal operation of the LLMs and this external prompt behavior.  I have a feeling there isn't, but it would be interesting to know more.--Fred

title: Add Chroma
body:
This PR adds Chroma as a vector store and Index on GPT Index. 

Chroma is an easy-to-use embeddings store. https://www.trychroma.com

title: Prevent Tree Index from querying LLM when there is only one node
body:
Address #451

Follows the same convention of calling `_query_with_selected_node` except it does not include the additional context of the `prev_response` since it did not generate a response.

title: Question: Indexing an csv file
body:
Hi Jerry, really thanks for this amazing library. Recently I am trying to embedding a csv about different issues, it is containing ard 1200 row and 30 col, each row is a issue. 

I query with the index and found that the model answer wrongly, there are some answer with mismatch of different issue and not able to have a summarized view of the csv.

May I know the suggested embedding method in gpt_index for embedding such data structure ?

Here is my code: 

`
def construct_index(directory_path):
   
    print("start of the indexing")

    # set maximum input size
    max_input_size = 4096
    # set number of output tokens
    num_outputs = 256
    # set maximum chunk overlap
    max_chunk_overlap = 20
    # set chunk size limit
    chunk_size_limit = 600

    # define LLM
    llm_predictor = LLMPredictor(llm=OpenAI(temperature=0, model_name="text-davinci-003", max_tokens=num_outputs))
    prompt_helper = PromptHelper(max_input_size, num_outputs, max_chunk_overlap, chunk_size_limit=chunk_size_limit)
 
    documents = SimpleDirectoryReader(directory_path).load_data()
    
    index = GPTSimpleVectorIndex(
        documents, llm_predictor=llm_predictor, prompt_helper=prompt_helper
    )

    index.save_to_disk('index4.json')
    print("end of the indexing")

    return index
`

title: Fix Qdrant client creation keyword arguments and cast payload correctly

This correctly creates the Qdrant client for QdrantReader. The correct keyword to specify Qdrant address is `url` instead of `host`.

Additionally casts the point's payload field from response to payload, instead of attempting to cast the full response.

this workflow:
- publishes gpt_index and llama_index packages to pypi
- creates a GH release

title: Add Option for Knowledge Graph Similarities
body:
This PR adds support for using embedding similarities within the knowledge graph index. 

You may have noticed that relying purely on keyword mapping for finding relation tuples may result in no relation tuples being found! If you didn't turn on the `include_text=True` option, then chances are the model will hallucinate an answer.

This PR allows you to use the existing keyword mapping, the top_k related knowledge graph tuples, or a combination of both!

The following is some example usage using both keywords and embeddings:
```
from gpt_index.data_structs.data_structs import  MODE_KEYWORDS, MODE_EMBEDDINGS
from gpt_index.indices.knowledge_graph.base import GPTKnowledgeGraphIndex

index = GPTKnowledgeGraphIndex(documents, llm_predictor=llm_predictor, mode=MODE_EMBEDDINGS+MODE_KEYWORDS)
response = index.query("What did the author do growing up?", include_text=False, similarity_cutoff=0.8, top_k_embeddings=1, response_mode="tree_summarize")
```

In my testing, the similarity cutoff is pretty important. Unrelated nodes are added to the prompt, it ends up hurting the response accuracy (maybe the prompt itself needs some investigation too 🤔)

title: How can I combine indexes or create a single index by using data with different data connectors?
body:
I want to pull data with different data connectors from multiple sources. Let's say I want data from my google docs, slack and a txt file. I understand how to do all of them one by one but what about if I want to create a single large index file that I can ask questions from?

What I tried was this kind of solution that I found from docs:

```
index1 = GPTSimpleVectorIndex(notion_docs)
index2 = GPTSimpleVectorIndex(slack_docs)

index1.set_text("summary1")
index2.set_text("summary2")

index3 = GPTListIndex([index1, index2])
```

But with this approach, the question/answer is not accurate anymore and does not find lots of things I am asking about that would work if I tried it on its own index only.

Another way that I tried that kind of worked was reading in all the documents and writing the content into a single file that I read in again later and index. But I would like to do it in a nicer way if possible.

Does anybody know how I can do this?

title: Update missing params typo in custom_llms.md
body: - README for custom LLMs is missing "documents" in initialization of GPTKeywordTableIndex

title: [WIP] Refactor Text Splitters to be composable, customizable, and less dependent on prompt
body:
This is a first stab at refactoring text splitters. The primary changes are:

- All indices accept a `text_splitter` which can be anything that inherits LangChain's `TextSplitter`. All the Text Splitters should work out of the box.
- Text Splitter is saved at the top level (`BaseGPTIndex`) and defaults to a TokenTextSplitter that doesn't depend on prompts
- The Tree Builder and Inserter still default to the text splitter generated by `PromptHelper` unless specified because otherwise prompt could overflow easily
- Same with `SQLContextBuilder` since lots of context is potentially pulled in
- Response builder is unchanged and still leverages PromptHelper when needed, which makes sense

Also adjusted a test case to accommodate the new pattern. Let me know your thoughts!

title: Allow batch of embeddings to vector store
body: Inspired by this issue #470 (thanks for the suggestion @ymansurozer!) Makes index construction of vector stores much faster. This is supported for all vector stores now (simple, faiss, pinecone, qdrant, weaviate) Here's an example pre-batching: Here's an example post-batching: Closes #470

title: How can I pass custom prompt to ComposableGraph?
remove duplication of stored information
body:
Current there is duplication for a given document in the json representation:
- document is stored in docstore
- document chunks/nodes are also stored in docstore
- chunks/nodes are also stored in index_struct

This PR consolidates all of that. We no longer store the raw document in the docstore. We also now remove storing index_struct separately.


Closes #377

title: support for keeping track of KG triplet sources
body:
This PR adds support for keeping track of which exact triplets were used to find answers to knowledge-graph queries. (https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/issues/463)

Previously, this was only accessible through tricky text parsing. Now, one can simply use `response.source_nodes`

Furthermore, this should support future "external sources", where the text used to compute an answer does not come directly from the source documents.

Happy to make any improvements to the code!

title: Why do we send embedding requests to Open AI one by one (one for each chunk) instead of batching them in a few requests?
body:
If I understand the codebase correctly, when I create an index, each chunk is sent as a single embedding request to Open AI, one after the other. However, we can batch them in an array and send the chunk array to Open AI in a single request, which is way faster. I tried, and creating a simple store index from a 100 pages document takes around a minute but with batching it takes 10 seconds. 

I know batching may cause issues for rate limits but we can create the chunks in a way to remain below 250k tokens per minute.

I really wonder the reason behind the current embedding strategy because I love the scability and scalability of GPT Index but it is slow even in small amounts of processing (even less than 50 pages).

title: add loader_hub_url to download_loader
body:
This will help users debug llama-hub contributions locally, by allowing users to pass in a `loader_hub_url` to `download_loader`.

The URL should be in the format `https://raw.githubusercontent.com/user/repository/branch/filename`.

For instance:
```
from gpt_index import download_loader

reader_cls = download_loader(
  "PDFReader", 
  loader_hub_url="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/emptycrown/llama-hub/jerry/add_debug_unstructured/loader_hub"
)
```

Is there any way to show which triplets were used to generate the answer? Similar to how vector search keeps track of the source text?

I'm happy to make a PR for this if you think it's possible, just trying to sort out the existing code for myself right now.

title: take 2: setup llama_index package
body:
paves the way for us to start creating duplicate llama_index pypi packages

created a simple helper script to build a package for llama_index. llama_index replaces all usages of gpt_index with llama_index (e.g. it's now `from llama_index import SimpleDirectoryReader`)

example usage to upload to pypi
```
LLAMA_INDEX_DIR=../llama_index GPT_INDEX_DIR=. sh create_llama_package.sh
cd ../llama_index
twine upload dist/llama_index-0.4.4.post2.tar.gz
```

title: QdrantIndex loses client in composability
body:
When creating a ComposableGraph over a composite index of Qdrant indices, queries error in

    File ...gpt_index/gpt_index/indices/query/vector_store/qdrant.py:61, in GPTQdrantIndexQuery.__init__(self, index_struct, embed_model, similarity_top_k, client, *
    *kwargs)
         58     raise ValueError(import_err_msg)
         60 if client is None:
    ---> 61     raise ValueError("client cannot be None.")
         63 self._client = cast(qdrant_client.QdrantClient, client)
    
    ValueError: client cannot be None.

Seems that the Qdrant client is not carried over to the composed index or graph. Created the query like this:

    i1 = GPTQdrantIndex([d1], client=client, collection_name="i1")
    i2 = GPTQdrantIndex([d2], client=client, collection_name="i2")
    li = GPTListIndex([i1, i2])
    graph  = ComposableGraph.build_from_index(li)

title: Using different Faiss indexes for large data
body:
I am trying to use `GPTFaissIndex` for storing vectors for about 5 million texts. The vectors (which I am generating from a sentence-transformers) model are of 384 dimensions. If I use a IndexFlatL2 faiss index, it does not scale well for the amount of data I have. Search would be slow and the memory footprint would be very high as well (which I want to avoid as I have limited resources). Since Faiss offers other optimized indexes that can be used (eg. IndexIVFScalarQuantizer), how do I go about using it through gpt_index? 

When I simply initialize the index and then try adding documents to it, I get the following error:
`RuntimeError: Error in virtual void faiss::IndexIVFScalarQuantizer::add_core(faiss::Index::idx_t, const float*, const idx_t*, const idx_t*) at /project/faiss/faiss/IndexScalarQuantizer.cpp:200: Error: 'is_trained' failed`

Code to reproduce error:
```
import faiss
from gpt_index import LangchainEmbedding, GPTFaissIndex, Document
from langchain.embeddings.huggingface import HuggingFaceEmbeddings

embed_model = LangchainEmbedding(HuggingFaceEmbeddings(
    model_name='sentence-transformers/multi-qa-MiniLM-L6-cos-v1'))   # d=384

d = 384  # dimension of the vectors
nlist = 5000  # number of clusters
quantizer = faiss.IndexFlatL2(d)  # the quantizer that maps data points to clusters
faiss_index = faiss.IndexIVFScalarQuantizer(quantizer, d, nlist, faiss.ScalarQuantizer.QT_8bit)

index = GPTFaissIndex([], faiss_index=faiss_index, embed_model=embed_model)

text_chunks = ["This is sentence A", "This is sentence B",  "This is sentence C"]
for text in text_chunks:
        embedding = embed_model.get_text_embedding(text)
        index.insert(Document(text, embedding=embedding))
```

Obviously, we will need to train the index at some point. But how do we do it with gpt_index?

And if this is something that's not possible, can you suggest what would be the best way we can use gpt index with data of ~5 million texts, 384-dimensional vectors, and ~64 GB of available RAM?  Looking for a good tradeoff between memory usage and performance.

title: Fix doc_id retrieval to nodes from Qdrant

title: How to fixed "ValueError: A single term is larger than the allowed chunk size."
body: Error msg: ValueError: A single term is larger than the allowed chunk size. Term size: 510 Chunk size: 379Effective chunk size: 379

title: Add Redis as a supported vector database
body:
Redis now allows for Vector storage, retrieval, similarity search, and hybrid querying/fitlering with the [RediSearch](https://redis.io/docs/stack/search/) module. It's rich developer ecosystem, low-latency, high-availability capabilities make this a good choice for dev teams looking to build LLM apps using a database they likely already have in their stack :)

This is something my team could help with.

title: Prevent LLM request on querying a tree with a single root node
body:
I have a tree index with non uniform shape. Some of the nodes have only a single child, and there is only one root node.

It seems like the `tree_index` query could be optimized something like:

```
cur_node_list = get_sorted_node_list(cur_nodes)
if len(cur_node_list) == 1:
    # jump to recursive call on leaf node
```

I am happy to make the PR to do this if the maintainers would like.

title: Is inserting documents to an index one by one slower than inserting the documents when setting up the index?
body:
I am using GPTFaissIndex as my index and am trying to insert about 6 million texts into it. I am initializing an empty GPTFaissIndex index first. 

The texts are first fetched from a SQL database and I am iterating over the fetched data one by one. In each iteration, I am splitting the text using text_splitter.split_text() before inserting the generated documents into the index by using index.insert() method. This works well, but the speed of insertion is very slow. Is there any way to speed this up? Will inserting all the documents at the same time during the initialization of the index improve the speed?

Relevant code snippet is added below for reference:
```
faiss_index = faiss.IndexFlatL2(768)
index = GPTFaissIndex([], faiss_index=faiss_index, embed_model=embed_model)

for d in sql_data_generator():    # This function yields row by row from the SQL database. Each row consists of id, title, description, url and publication_date
    try:
        text_chunks = text_splitter.split_text(d['description'])  
    except ValueError:
        continue
    for text in text_chunks:
        embedding = embed_model.get_text_embedding(text)   
        document = Document(text, embedding=embedding, 
                                  extra_info={
                                      "id": d['id'],
                                      "title": d['title'],
                                      "url": d['url'],
                                      "publication_date": str(d['publication_date'])}
                                 )
        index.insert(document)
```

title: doc_id missing from source_nodes in GPTQdrantIndex queries
body:
If I query against GPTSimpleVectorIndex, the response has source nodes that can be looked at to determine the original document id. Very useful behavior.

If I query against GPTQdrantIndex, source nodes don't have this information.

Looking at the GPTQdrant index creation code, doc_id seems to enter the index as payload though. 

Problem is Probably here

    @dataclass
    class SourceNode(DataClassJsonMixin):
        """Source node.
    
        User-facing class containing the source text and the corresponding document id.
    
        """
    
        source_text: str
        doc_id: Optional[str]
        extra_info: Optional[Dict[str, Any]] = None
        node_info: Optional[Dict[str, Any]] = None
    
        # distance score between node and query, if applicable
        similarity: Optional[float] = None
    
        @classmethod
        def from_node(cls, node: Node, similarity: Optional[float] = None) -> "SourceNode":
            """Create a SourceNode from a Node."""
            from IPython import embed; embed()
            return cls(
                source_text=node.get_text(),
                doc_id=node.ref_doc_id,
                extra_info=node.extra_info,
                node_info=node.node_info,
                similarity=similarity,
            )

`doc_id ` looks for `ref_doc_id`

Why does the behavior differ between indexes?

title: Chunk size can be negative
body:
I'm using a custom prompt_helper, as follows:

```
# define prompt helper
# set number of output tokens
num_output = 512
# set maximum input size
max_input_size = 2048
# set maximum chunk overlap
max_chunk_overlap = 20

chunk_size_limit = max_input_size - num_output

prompt_helper = PromptHelper(max_input_size, num_output, max_chunk_overlap, chunk_size_limit=chunk_size_limit)
```

When running on the `paul_graham_essay` example, I get errors like this:

`ValueError: Got a larger chunk overlap (20) than chunk size (-77), should be smaller.`

The code should probably be preventing this from happening 🤔 I think it's because the prompt size is getting bigger than max_input_size

title: Enable naive async support in `LLMPredictor` and `GPTTreeIndexBuilder`
body:
### API changes
* Expose `use_async` param in `GPTTreeIndex` ctor (default to False).
* Expose `use_async` param in `BaseGPTIndex.query` API (default to False).
> To propagate this param, we also add `use_async` to `QueryRunner` and `BaseGPTIndexQuery` ctors.

### Summary
* Support async predict in `LLMPredictor`
* Support naive (per level) async index building in `GPTTreeIndexBuilder`
> Use async event loop to process nodes in each level (still blocking before moving onto next level).
* Add demo notebooks

title: Adds an AsanaReader for loading tasks from a workspace
Best llm to use gpt_index
body: OpenAI's models definitely have high quality. But suppose someone wants to achieve comparable results using self host models and gpt-index, what are the alternatives?

title: More flexible answer generation
body:
Really like the interface and very impressed with the quick progress on the package! I've been exploring different approaches to using the raw value returned from documents in question answering. I did some experiments and found that instead of the refining approach, it works better for me to do a "hierarchical" approach and summarize and then combine. [See overview here](https://github.com/whitead/paper-qa).

I did find a way to get the raw sources out via this approach:

```py
query = gpt_index.indices.query.vector_store.simple.GPTSimpleVectorIndexQuery(
                        index.index_struct,
                        similarity_top_k=k,
                        embed_model=index.embed_model,
                        prompt_helper=lambda: None,  # dummy
                    )
queries[index] = query
query = queries[index]
nodes = query.get_nodes_and_similarities_for_response(question)
```

This was fine, but I couldn't figure out how to store the metadata I wanted in the nodes too. Maybe this is me missing something in the docs, but I wanted to store page numbers in the metadata to use later on. I couldn't figure out how to do that though.

## TL;DR

So here's what I would propose:

- [ ] Have two paths for answering: one based on refinement, one based on summarizing from multiple sources [see prompts](https://github.com/whitead/paper-qa/blob/main/paperqa/qaprompts.py)
- [ ] Enable metadata to be stored with documents that can be access in prompt templates
- [ ] Make it possible to easily get nodes - without instantiating query obj
- [ ] [minor] Expose max_marginal for FAISS (maybe already done?) - which I found improves diversity of responses

These are just my observations in my use-case, it seems that gpt-index has been very successful for others. 
I'm happy to help write code on this - in fact I tried to - but this seems to involve some deep rethinking of library. So - happy to discuss and contribute where I can - but will need help from gpt-index team.

title: Refactor download_loader to how loaders are downloaded.
body:
This PR changes how loaders are downloaded from `llama-hub`. Originally, we downloaded readers under `.modules` directory.
I propose that we create a directory called `modules` and make it a python module and download the readers under their corresponding directories such as `modules/s3`, `modules/discord` etc.

And we will have to update each loaders __init__.py in the llama-hub with:
```python
from .base import <ReaderClassName>
from .<extra_file_name> import <ExtraClassName>
```

This allows us the use the downloaded readers as follows
```python
from gpt_index import download_loader

download_loader("GithubRepositoryReader")
from modules.github_repo import GithubClient, GithubRepositoryReader

if __name__ == "__main__":
    github_client = GithubClient(...)
    loader = GithubRepositoryReader(github_client=github_client, ...)

   S3Reader = download_loader("S3Reader")
   s3_reader = S3Reader(...)
```

It doesn't break how we were originally using the download_loader.

While I was working on this PR. I found out that `raw.githubusercontent.com` doesn't update the content of the file immediately. See the following stackoverflow question: [github-not-update-raw-after-commit](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46551413/github-not-update-raw-after-commit). In my case the cache max-age was 24 hours.

So, I used `https://api.github.com/repos/{OWNER}/{REPO}/contents/{PATH}` GitHub REST API endpoint. It works without access token. The only caveat is that the rate limit for unauthorized requests is 600 per hour.

title: Introduce `QueryTransform` and add `HyDEQueryTransform`
body:
### Summary
* Introduce concept of `QueryProcessor` and simple implementation of HyDE query processor 
* Naive integration with `QueryRunner` where we run query processor once
* Add HyDE example to notebook for demo

### TLDR
```
query_processor = HyDEQueryProcessor(include_original=True)
response = index.query("what did author do after going to RISD", query_processor=query_processor)
``` 

### Future work
- Support generating multiple hypothetical docs
- Consider refactor to support index-specific query processing

title: Refactor to support customization of embedding string(s)
body:
### Summary
* Refactor query interface to use `QueryBundle` instead of raw `str` 
* This allows users to explicitly use different string(s) for embedding-based queries and non-embedding based queries. 

### TLDR
```
query_bundle = QueryBundle(
    query_str="What did the author do growing up?", 
    custom_embedding_strs=['The author grew up painting and coding.']
)
response = index.query(query_bundle)
``` 

### Future work
* This refactor sets stage for https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/pull/437

title: fix: rss reader entry content attr not found bug
when pickle.dumps the index got a error {AttributeError}Can't pickle local object 'GlobalsHelper.tokenizer.<locals>.tokenizer_fn'
Add Basic Knowledge Graph Structure
body:
Adds triplet extraction + a KG structure for storing and retrieving information.

Since we still ultimately return the whole node in the response, this format doesn't give us much additional sparsity, so a natural extension to this would be a method of returning just a serialized string of "Subject predicate object. Subject predicate object. ..."

title: Added Pinecone kwargs to all index operations to allow the use of namespaces
Return nodes/documents associated with a response.
body: When returning a response, based on an index and query, e.g. response = index.query(query, response_mode="default"), it would be nice to have some traceback to the nodes and/or documents that contributed to the response (but not all nodes and documents that created the index). I can't really see a way to do this. Any thoughts would be appreciated.

title: How to handle large index files?
body:
Hello there, I am currently having couple of issues/questions I'd like to get advice on:
- How do we handle large index.json files? I have index file which is more than 100MB
- If I want to train the model but with different topic, should I [update](https://gpt-index.readthedocs.io/en/latest/how_to/update.html) existing index or create a new index?
- Is there a way for gpt_index to handle multiple index files?
- Large JSON files works fine locally but if you want to deploy app to services like Google Cloud or AWS what stack are you all using?
Thank you
